user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtAssert_DoTestSegmentReport:
```c
void UtAssert_DoTestSegmentReport(const char *SegmentName, const UtAssert_TestCounter_t *TestCounters)
{
    char ReportBuffer[144];

    snprintf(ReportBuffer, sizeof(ReportBuffer),
             "%-22s ABORT::%-4u  WARN::%-4u  FLOW::%-4u  DEBUG::%-4u  N/A::%-4u",
             "",
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_WARN],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FLOW],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_DEBUG],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_NA]);

    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_INFO, ReportBuffer);

    snprintf(ReportBuffer, sizeof(ReportBuffer),
             "%02u %-20s TOTAL::%-4u  PASS::%-4u  FAIL::%-4u  MIR::%-4u  TSF::%-4u  TTF::%-4u",
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->TestSegmentCount, SegmentName, (unsigned int)TestCounters->TotalTestCases,
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_PASS],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FAILURE],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_MIR],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TSF],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TTF]);

    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_END, ReportBuffer);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No suspicious fragments found. The function parameters are used only for read access: SegmentName is passed to snprintf and not assigned to or incremented/decremented, and TestCounters is dereferenced to read fields (modifying the object pointed-to would be permitted by the rule, but this code only reads values). There are no assignments to the pointer parameters (no statements like SegmentName = ... or TestCounters = ...), no pointer arithmetic on them, and they are not cast to a non-const pointer or passed to a callee in a way that would modify the pointer itself. Therefore no code in this function appears to violate Rule 17.8 and nothing needs to be further investigated for that rule.
